conclusion: Understanding the p-V diagram with two adiabatic and two isochoric processes for an ideal gas cycle.
Recalling definitions: Adiabatic (Q=0) and Isochoric (ΔV=0) processes.
Cycle path: a to d to b to c and back to a; adiabatic processes are curved, isochoric are vertical lines.
Net work done by the system equals the area enclosed by the cycle on the p-V diagram.
For a cycle, ΔU = Q - W = 0, so Q = W.
Net heat absorbed equals the area enclosed by the cycle, representing net work done.
Cycle encloses an area where the system does work on the surroundings, indicating positive W and Q.
From a to d: Isochoric process, volume constant, pressure decreases.
Isochoric process a to d: W=0, Q = ΔU.
From d to b: Adiabatic expansion, pressure decreases, volume increases.
Adiabatic process d to b: Q=0, W positive, ΔU negative.
From b to c: Isochoric process, pressure increases at constant volume.
Isochoric process b to c: W=0, Q = ΔU.
From c to a: Adiabatic compression, pressure increases, volume decreases.
Adiabatic process c to a: Q=0, W negative, ΔU positive.
Net heat absorbed Q_net = ΔU1 + ΔU3.
Net change in internal energy ΔU_total = 0 for the cycle.
Re-evaluating: W_net = Q_net, with W2 positive and W4 negative.
Area enclosed is positive, indicating W_net > 0, hence Q_net > 0.
